text: How is the foundation or generative AI model sourced for your product?

options.label: Self-trained
options.description: Your organization trained the model from scratch

options.label: Third-party API
options.description: You access a model via API (e.g., OpenAI, Anthropic, Google)

options.label: Fine-tuned
options.description: You fine-tuned a pre-existing model on your own data

options.label: Open-source model
options.description: You deploy an open-source model (e.g., Llama, Mistral, Falcon)

regulatoryRelevance: Model sourcing determines provider vs. deployer obligations under the EU AI Act, training data compliance responsibilities, and accountability allocation across all jurisdictions.

text: What specific model(s) does your product use? (e.g., GPT-4, Claude 3, Llama 3, Stable Diffusion XL)
regulatoryRelevance: Identifying the specific model is needed for transparency notices, algorithm filing (China), and downstream documentation requirements.

text: What types of content does your system generate? Select all that apply.

options.label: Text
options.description: Written content, summaries, translations, code comments

options.label: Images
options.description: Generated or edited images, illustrations, designs

options.label: Audio
options.description: Speech synthesis, music generation, sound effects

options.label: Video
options.description: Generated or edited video content

options.label: Code
options.description: Generated source code, scripts, or configurations

options.label: Multimodal
options.description: Combines multiple output types (e.g., text + images)

regulatoryRelevance: Output modalities determine which content labeling, watermarking, and disclosure requirements apply. Image/video/audio generation triggers deepfake and synthetic media regulations in multiple jurisdictions.

text: Can the system generate realistic synthetic media of real people (deepfakes)? This includes realistic face swaps, voice cloning, or body puppetry.
regulatoryRelevance: Deepfake capabilities trigger specific regulations in China (deep synthesis rules), EU (AI Act Article 50), US states (California, Texas deepfake laws), and disclosure requirements across all jurisdictions.

text: Can the system generate synthetic voice or clone existing voices?
regulatoryRelevance: Voice cloning and synthetic speech trigger disclosure requirements under the EU AI Act Article 50, China deep synthesis regulations, and multiple US state laws.

text: Does the system have content safety filters applied to generated output?
regulatoryRelevance: Content safety filtering is required by China's CAC GenAI measures, expected under EU AI Act systemic risk provisions, and considered best practice under NIST AI RMF GenAI profile and Singapore IMDA guidelines.

text: Does the system label or watermark AI-generated content (e.g., C2PA metadata, visible labels, embedded watermarks)?
regulatoryRelevance: AI-generated content labeling is mandatory under China's CAC GenAI measures, required by EU AI Act Article 50, required by California SB 942, and recommended by Singapore IMDA and NIST GenAI profile.

text: What categories of data were used to train or fine-tune the model? Select all that apply.

options.label: Public web scrape
options.description: Data scraped from publicly available websites

options.label: Licensed datasets
options.description: Data obtained through licensing agreements

options.label: User-generated content
options.description: Content created by users of your platform

options.label: Proprietary data
options.description: Internally owned organizational data

options.label: Synthetic data
options.description: AI-generated data used for training

options.label: Copyrighted works
options.description: Books, articles, music, images under copyright

options.label: Personal data
options.description: Data relating to identifiable individuals

options.label: Government/public records
options.description: Official government datasets or public records

options.label: Open-source datasets
options.description: Publicly available ML datasets (Common Crawl, LAION, etc.)

regulatoryRelevance: Training data composition affects EU AI Act copyright compliance (Article 53), China CAC training data legality requirements, GDPR lawful basis for personal data, and Brazil AI Bill disclosure obligations.

text: Did you fine-tune the model on your own data?
regulatoryRelevance: Fine-tuning creates additional data governance obligations and may shift some provider-level responsibilities to the deployer under the EU AI Act and China's CAC measures.

text: Describe the data used for fine-tuning: its source, size, whether it contains personal data, and whether consent was obtained.
regulatoryRelevance: Fine-tuning data provenance is relevant for GDPR lawful basis, EU AI Act training data documentation, and China CAC training data legality requirements.

text: Does your system use retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) â€” retrieving documents or data to augment model responses?
regulatoryRelevance: RAG systems may process personal data from retrieved documents, creating additional data protection obligations. The retrieval corpus composition affects accuracy, bias, and transparency obligations.

text: Can the AI system take autonomous actions beyond generating content (e.g., calling APIs, executing code, browsing the web, sending messages)?
regulatoryRelevance: Agentic capabilities trigger additional requirements under Singapore's IMDA Agentic AI Framework, EU AI Act human oversight provisions, and may affect risk classification across jurisdictions.

text: Has the algorithm been filed with China's Cyberspace Administration (CAC)?

options.label: Not filed
options.description: No filing has been made with the CAC

options.label: Filed
options.description: Filing has been submitted and is under review

options.label: Approved
options.description: Filing has been approved by the CAC

options.label: Not applicable
options.description: Service is not offered in China or is exempt

regulatoryRelevance: China's CAC Interim Measures for Generative AI Services require algorithm filing before public launch. Non-compliance can result in service shutdown and penalties.

text: Does the system provide content moderation capabilities to ensure generated content complies with Chinese laws and regulations?
regulatoryRelevance: China's CAC GenAI measures require providers to implement content review mechanisms ensuring outputs align with socialist core values and do not contain prohibited content.

text: Does this model meet the UK AI Safety Institute's criteria for a frontier model (i.e., a highly capable foundation model that may pose risks)?

options.label: Yes
options.description: The model is considered a frontier model by AISI criteria

options.label: No
options.description: The model does not meet frontier model criteria

options.label: Unknown
options.description: Unsure whether the model qualifies as a frontier model

regulatoryRelevance: UK AISI frontier model framework applies additional safety evaluation requirements and voluntary commitments (transitioning to mandatory) for frontier AI models.

text: Does your organization follow the IMDA's GenAI governance guidelines (Model AI Governance Framework GenAI addendum)?
regulatoryRelevance: Singapore's IMDA GenAI governance framework provides guidance on testing, evaluation, incident reporting, content provenance, and disclosure obligations for GenAI products.
